Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as irresponsible, unreasonable, and limiting fundamental rights.
The bill is perceived as a threat to free speech and an unlawful interference by the government.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation are problematic and could lead to misuse of power.
The bill grants excessive powers to the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) and excludes certain content from scrutiny, which is seen as dangerous.
The legislation is viewed as a breach of human rights, particularly freedom of expression.
The penalties associated with the bill are considered draconian and harmful to individuals and service providers.
The bill is seen as a threat to privacy, particularly concerning private messages and information held by digital providers.
Notable Quotes: It is one of the worst pieces of legislation introduced into parliament, because it is irresponsible, beyond unreasonable and limits fundamental rights.
This proposed legislation is extremely dangerous and harmful and ostensibly silences anyone from engaging in critical discussion.
I am vehemently against this bill. I believe it to be Orwellian in nature, the measures are draconian and unlawful and will be used to control information under the guise of protecting Australians.
